Will FIFA World Cup 2026 be transformative for soccer in the USA?
Source: FOX 29 Philadelphia    Published: 2025-08-16 14:30:37

Share Ticket registration for the 2026 FIFA World Cup is now open! PHILADELPHIA, Pa. - In 1994, the United States hosted its first-ever FIFA World Cup, and it was a historic event that many believe planted the seeds for the sport's growth in the nation. The tournament proved that the U.S. could host the world's biggest event, and it led to the creation of Major League Soccer (MLS), a crucial step in building a professional league from the ground up. But soccer (or football), for the most part, remained a "niche sport" that many Americans only paid semi-attention to every four years. And in June 2026, 16 cities in Canada, Mexico and the United States will host a record 48 international teams for the FIFA World Cup. Times have changed dramatically since the 1994 World Cup. Today, the sight of a Premier League jersey has become a common one, with fans of teams like Liverpool, Manchester United, Arsenal and Chelsea growing in number. The recent success of clubs like Manchester City has also fueled a rise in popularity, making Premier League soccer a growing force in the American sports landscape. American fans will likely be able to see world-class players like Kylian Mbappé (France), Erling Haaland (Norway) and Vinicius Jr. (Brazil), as well as legends of the game Lionel Messi (Argentina) and Cristiano Ronaldo (Portugal), depending on how the final qualifiers for the tournament play out, injuries and potential retirements. Lionel Messi of Argentina celebrates with the World Cup trophy at the end of the FIFA World Cup Qatar 2022 Final match between Argentina and France at Lusail Stadium on December 18, 2022 in Lusail City, Qatar. (Photo by Chris Brunskill/Fantasista/Get When the FIFA World Cup 2026 kicks off, it will find a nation with a much deeper connection to the sport. The game is no longer an international curiosity, but an everyday reality. Thanks to NBC-exclusive broadcasting rights bringing the Premier League to American televisions, and streaming services like Peacock and Paramount Plus, fans have unprecedented access to top leagues like the Premier League and Champions League. ESPN+ also makes the Spanish premier division, La Liga, available, as well as Germany's Bundesliga. We've already seen the passion in person, with incredible fan support for both American and international club teams at the FIFA Club World Cup this summer, which saw Chelsea Football Club lift the major silverware at the MetLife Stadium in New Jersey after defeating French champions Paris Saint-Germain F.C. As for the World Cup itself, it's a unique and special event. It's important to remember that the famous athletes who will be entering the stadiums are not playing for their club teams, but are instead coming together to play for their national teams after being called up by their national team coach. This allows for a deeper level of national pride. 2025 FIFA Club World Cup at the Lincoln Financial Field, Chelsea v. Palmeiras. (Photo: Tyler Thrasher/FOX TV Stations) What's next: Major League Soccer has also grown into something much bigger in recent years, with a strong grassroots foundation for the sport here in the United States. The 2026 World Cup is more than just a tournament; it's an opportunity to show the world how far American soccer has come and how far it has yet to go. While 1994 may have planted the seeds, 2026 might be the moment the plant finally blossoms into a national obsession. "I think the World Cup will help the sport in America. It hopefully will improve participation country-wide due to the increased visibility of the sport," Alex Washburn, a soccer player in the Premier Division of the Central Virginia Soccer Association (CVSA) and Everton F.C. fan, said. "It should have the local areas across the USA buzzing in the months leading up to the games." With marquee players signing for clubs in the MLS like Lionel Messi, Thierry Henry, David Beckham, Zlatan Ibrahimović, Wayne Rooney and Frank Lampard, the sport has grown more popular each time a global superstar makes their debut on American soil. However, most of the time, players of their caliber come toward the end of their careers in the biggest leagues in Europe. These superstars have also noticed the differences between the way soccer is ingrained in other countries and the accessibility issues the sport faces in the United States. During Ibrahimović's time in the MLS with L.A. Galaxy, the Swedish striker had an up-close look at the developmental system in the United States and was critical of what he saw. He pointed to the "pay-to-play" system, where young players and their families are expected to pay to join a club, while speaking with GQ Italy in 2019. This, he argued, is a direct contrast to much of the rest of the world where organized soccer is not a commodity as much as it is a community, and young talent can emerge from all economic backgrounds. This is seen by many as a key hurdle for the U.S. to overcome in producing world-class talent. While Major League Soccer may not yet be thought of as a premier destination for the world's best overseas footballers, the league's consistent growth can cultivate and produce world-class talent. The FIFA World Cup qualifiers will conclude in mid-November, revealing the 48 nations that will bring the tournament to North America and spark a new generation of soccer fans. For a full list of cities hosting games for the FIFA World Cup 2026, visit FIFA's website. The Source: Information provided by FIFA was used in this article. All the news you need to know, every day By clicking Sign Up, I confirmthat I have read and agreeto the Privacy Policy and Terms of Service. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. ©2025 FOX Television Stations
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Newcastle's Alexander Isak replacement? Magpies interested in PSG striker Goncalo Ramos should Swedish star depart for Liverpool
Source: Goal.com    Published: 2025-08-16 14:11:45

Newcastle United's hunt for a new frontman has swung dramatically back to Paris-Saint Germain striker Goncalo Ramos, with reports revealing that the 24-year-old has resurfaced as a genuine option at St. James' Park. Earlier this month, the Portugal international was brushed aside as an unlikely target after initial probes suggested PSG were unwilling to budge.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


FIFA World Cup Fan Festival in Miami: How Forty Six Million USD Will Drive Tourism Growth
Source: Travel And Tour World    Published: 2025-08-16 12:42:07

Published on August 16, 2025 Miami-Dade County will spend 46 million USD on the 2026 FIFA World Cup, including money for the FIFA Fan Festival in downtown Miami. This big-ticket item is raising eyebrows since the county is also eyeing cuts to other local services. Even with the debate, the plan will roll out a three-week soccer bash that mingles visitors from around the globe with Miami locals.The FIFA Fan Festival is the beating heart of Miami's World Cup lineup. It will fill Bayfront Park and remain free for everyone. Fans can catch the matches live on big screens, rock out at concerts, and dive into a mix of other entertainment. The festival promises to keep the World Cup spirit alive for those without match tickets, creating a colorful, open-space party for all.Advertisement Funding Breakdown: What Miami-Dade's 46 Million USD Will CoverMiami-Dade County's substantial contribution to the World Cup budget includes 25 million USD in public safety services and 21 million USD in cash to fund local events and services. The 21 million USD will cover a range of expenses, including those for the FIFA Fan Festival. However, specific allocations for the festival itself have not been fully disclosed, although it is expected to be one of the largest events funded by the county. According to local planning documents, the Fan Festival is the primary event mentioned, suggesting it will be a significant focus of the budget.In addition to the Fan Festival, the county's contributions will cover other logistical aspects of hosting the World Cup, including transportation, volunteer programs, and the creation of a local-preference contracting organization. The last mile transportation system, a critical component of the World Cup's transit plans, will ensure that fans can reach Hard Rock Stadium and other venues efficiently, particularly given the limited parking availability. Many ticket holders will likely need to rely on buses provided by FIFA to travel to and from the stadiums.FIFA Fan Festival: A Major Event for Locals and VisitorsThe FIFA Fan Festival is set to be one of Miami's most significant events ever, according to the host committee's budget projections. The event will run for 10 hours a day across a three-week period, bringing a carnival-like atmosphere to Bayfront Park. Festival-goers will enjoy large-scale match viewings on oversized screens, live music performances, Miami-themed entertainment, and a wide range of food and beverages. The festival is expected to attract both local fans and visitors from around the world, all eager to participate in the excitement surrounding the World Cup.Rodney Barreto, volunteer chair of the local host committee, emphasized that the Fan Festival provides an alternative venue for those without tickets, reducing the risk of large crowds congregating outside Hard Rock Stadium. It's designed as a space for people to come together and celebrate soccer without the need for a stadium ticket, ensuring that everyone has the chance to experience the global event.Moreover, the Fan Festival is expected to play a key role in attracting private sponsorships, helping cover additional World Cup-related expenses. Sponsors will be able to activate their brands inside Bayfront Park, benefiting from the exposure to the thousands of fans expected to attend the festival.The Budget Controversy: A Balancing ActThe decision to allocate 46 million USD for the World Cup has sparked debates among Miami-Dade's political leaders. Critics, such as State Senator Ileana Garcia, have pointed to the World Cup funding as an example of how the county is prioritizing sports events over crucial social services. In particular, Garcia has argued that the money spent on the World Cup should be redirected to local programs such as senior meals and adult day care, which have seen cuts in the proposed 2026 budget.Despite these concerns, Miami-Dade officials, including Mayor Daniella Levine Cava, have defended the spending, noting that the county had actively competed to host World Cup matches and is now obligated to fund its share of the event's costs. The mayor has also acknowledged that the budget for World Cup-related expenses could be revisited during upcoming budget hearings in September.A Significant Tourism Boost for MiamiThe FIFA World Cup's presence in Miami is poised to deliver a significant boost to the city's tourism industry. With thousands of international fans flocking to the city, local businesses, hotels, restaurants, and attractions will likely see an influx of visitors. Additionally, Miami's status as a major international destination will be further solidified as the event shines a global spotlight on the city. The Fan Festival, in particular, will help extend the World Cup experience to a wider audience, ensuring that even those without tickets can enjoy the festivities.In addition to the economic benefits, the event also highlights Miami's growing prominence as a cultural and entertainment hub. The city's diverse offerings, from its vibrant nightlife to its rich cultural heritage, will complement the global energy surrounding the World Cup, attracting even more travelers in the years to come.Miami's World Cup Investment and its Impact on Local TourismMiami-Dade County's 46 million USD push for the 2026 FIFA World Cup is big news for everyone, from lifelong locals to the fans flying in for the games. The FIFA Fan Festival is the centerpiece everyone should circle on their calendars. Free to enter, it's the ultimate soccer block party where you can watch every match on giant screens, enjoy food from around the world, and feel the stadium buzz without ever buying a ticket. Sure, some folks question the price tag, but the payoff in hotel bookings, restaurant lines, and airport crowds is hard to ignore. A million fans wandering around the Magic City turns the whole stretch from Little Havana to South Beach into one giant global pep rally and locks in Miami's rep as a travel hotspot.From upgraded Brightline trains ready to zip you from the airport to the stadium, to the new downtown quick-pass lane for rideshare and 24-hour police patrols, Miami is putting pencil to plans for a World Cup travel experience you won't forget. The heartbeat will be a three-week run where you can hear the wave on one block, smell croquetas on the next, and watch superstars score on the big screens. It's the perfect kickoff for the years of tourism to come.Advertisement Share On:Tags: 2026 World Cup, FIFA events, FIFA Fan Festival, Miami, World Cup fundingSubscribe to our NewslettersFollow Travel And Tour World in Google News The FIFA Fan Festival is the beating heart of Miami's World Cup lineup. It will fill Bayfront Park and remain free for everyone. Fans can catch the matches live on big screens, rock out at concerts, and dive into a mix of other entertainment. The festival promises to keep the World Cup spirit alive for those without match tickets, creating a colorful, open-space party for all.Advertisement Funding Breakdown: What Miami-Dade's 46 Million USD Will CoverMiami-Dade County's substantial contribution to the World Cup budget includes 25 million USD in public safety services and 21 million USD in cash to fund local events and services. The 21 million USD will cover a range of expenses, including those for the FIFA Fan Festival. However, specific allocations for the festival itself have not been fully disclosed, although it is expected to be one of the largest events funded by the county. According to local planning documents, the Fan Festival is the primary event mentioned, suggesting it will be a significant focus of the budget.In addition to the Fan Festival, the county's contributions will cover other logistical aspects of hosting the World Cup, including transportation, volunteer programs, and the creation of a local-preference contracting organization. Many ticket holders will likely need to rely on buses provided by FIFA to travel to and from the stadiums.FIFA Fan Festival: A Major Event for Locals and VisitorsThe FIFA Fan Festival is set to be one of Miami's most significant events ever, according to the host committee's budget projections. The event will run for 10 hours a day across a three-week period, bringing a carnival-like atmosphere to Bayfront Park. It's designed as a space for people to come together and celebrate soccer without the need for a stadium ticket, ensuring that everyone has the chance to experience the global event.Moreover, the Fan Festival is expected to play a key role in attracting private sponsorships, helping cover additional World Cup-related expenses. Sponsors will be able to activate their brands inside Bayfront Park, benefiting from the exposure to the thousands of fans expected to attend the festival.The Budget Controversy: A Balancing ActThe decision to allocate 46 million USD for the World Cup has sparked debates among Miami-Dade's political leaders. Critics, such as State Senator Ileana Garcia, have pointed to the World Cup funding as an example of how the county is prioritizing sports events over crucial social services. In particular, Garcia has argued that the money spent on the World Cup should be redirected to local programs such as senior meals and adult day care, which have seen cuts in the proposed 2026 budget.Despite these concerns, Miami-Dade officials, including Mayor Daniella Levine Cava, have defended the spending, noting that the county had actively competed to host World Cup matches and is now obligated to fund its share of the event's costs. The mayor has also acknowledged that the budget for World Cup-related expenses could be revisited during upcoming budget hearings in September.A Significant Tourism Boost for MiamiThe FIFA World Cup's presence in Miami is poised to deliver a significant boost to the city's tourism industry. With thousands of international fans flocking to the city, local businesses, hotels, restaurants, and attractions will likely see an influx of visitors. Additionally, Miami's status as a major international destination will be further solidified as the event shines a global spotlight on the city. The Fan Festival, in particular, will help extend the World Cup experience to a wider audience, ensuring that even those without tickets can enjoy the festivities.In addition to the economic benefits, the event also highlights Miami's growing prominence as a cultural and entertainment hub. The city's diverse offerings, from its vibrant nightlife to its rich cultural heritage, will complement the global energy surrounding the World Cup, attracting even more travelers in the years to come.Miami's World Cup Investment and its Impact on Local TourismMiami-Dade County's 46 million USD push for the 2026 FIFA World Cup is big news for everyone, from lifelong locals to the fans flying in for the games. The FIFA Fan Festival is the centerpiece everyone should circle on their calendars. Free to enter, it's the ultimate soccer block party where you can watch every match on giant screens, enjoy food from around the world, and feel the stadium buzz without ever buying a ticket. Sure, some folks question the price tag, but the payoff in hotel bookings, restaurant lines, and airport crowds is hard to ignore. A million fans wandering around the Magic City turns the whole stretch from Little Havana to South Beach into one giant global pep rally and locks in Miami's rep as a travel hotspot.From upgraded Brightline trains ready to zip you from the airport to the stadium, to the new downtown quick-pass lane for rideshare and 24-hour police patrols, Miami is putting pencil to plans for a World Cup travel experience you won't forget. The heartbeat will be a three-week run where you can hear the wave on one block, smell croquetas on the next, and watch superstars score on the big screens. It's the perfect kickoff for the years of tourism to come.Advertisement Share On:Tags: 2026 World Cup, FIFA events, FIFA Fan Festival, Miami, World Cup fundingSubscribe to our NewslettersFollow Travel And Tour World in Google News Advertisement Miami-Dade County's substantial contribution to the World Cup budget includes 25 million USD in public safety services and 21 million USD in cash to fund local events and services. The FIFA Fan Festival is the centerpiece everyone should circle on their calendars. Free to enter, it's the ultimate soccer block party where you can watch every match on giant screens, enjoy food from around the world, and feel the stadium buzz without ever buying a ticket. Sure, some folks question the price tag, but the payoff in hotel bookings, restaurant lines, and airport crowds is hard to ignore. A million fans wandering around the Magic City turns the whole stretch from Little Havana to South Beach into one giant global pep rally and locks in Miami's rep as a travel hotspot.From upgraded Brightline trains ready to zip you from the airport to the stadium, to the new downtown quick-pass lane for rideshare and 24-hour police patrols, Miami is putting pencil to plans for a World Cup travel experience you won't forget. The heartbeat will be a three-week run where you can hear the wave on one block, smell croquetas on the next, and watch superstars score on the big screens. It's the perfect kickoff for the years of tourism to come.Advertisement Share On:Tags: 2026 World Cup, FIFA events, FIFA Fan Festival, Miami, World Cup fundingSubscribe to our NewslettersFollow Travel And Tour World in Google News In addition to the Fan Festival, the county's contributions will cover other logistical aspects of hosting the World Cup, including transportation, volunteer programs, and the creation of a local-preference contracting organization. The last mile transportation system, a critical component of the World Cup's transit plans, will ensure that fans can reach Hard Rock Stadium and other venues efficiently, particularly given the limited parking availability. Many ticket holders will likely need to rely on buses provided by FIFA to travel to and from the stadiums.FIFA Fan Festival: A Major Event for Locals and VisitorsThe FIFA Fan Festival is set to be one of Miami's most significant events ever, according to the host committee's budget projections. The event will run for 10 hours a day across a three-week period, bringing a carnival-like atmosphere to Bayfront Park. Festival-goers will enjoy large-scale match viewings on oversized screens, live music performances, Miami-themed entertainment, and a wide range of food and beverages. The festival is expected to attract both local fans and visitors from around the world, all eager to participate in the excitement surrounding the World Cup.Rodney Barreto, volunteer chair of the local host committee, emphasized that the Fan Festival provides an alternative venue for those without tickets, reducing the risk of large crowds congregating outside Hard Rock Stadium. It's designed as a space for people to come together and celebrate soccer without the need for a stadium ticket, ensuring that everyone has the chance to experience the global event.Moreover, the Fan Festival is expected to play a key role in attracting private sponsorships, helping cover additional World Cup-related expenses. Sponsors will be able to activate their brands inside Bayfront Park, benefiting from the exposure to the thousands of fans expected to attend the festival.The Budget Controversy: A Balancing ActThe decision to allocate 46 million USD for the World Cup has sparked debates among Miami-Dade's political leaders. Critics, such as State Senator Ileana Garcia, have pointed to the World Cup funding as an example of how the county is prioritizing sports events over crucial social services. In particular, Garcia has argued that the money spent on the World Cup should be redirected to local programs such as senior meals and adult day care, which have seen cuts in the proposed 2026 budget.Despite these concerns, Miami-Dade officials, including Mayor Daniella Levine Cava, have defended the spending, noting that the county had actively competed to host World Cup matches and is now obligated to fund its share of the event's costs. The mayor has also acknowledged that the budget for World Cup-related expenses could be revisited during upcoming budget hearings in September.A Significant Tourism Boost for MiamiThe FIFA World Cup's presence in Miami is poised to deliver a significant boost to the city's tourism industry. With thousands of international fans flocking to the city, local businesses, hotels, restaurants, and attractions will likely see an influx of visitors. Additionally, Miami's status as a major international destination will be further solidified as the event shines a global spotlight on the city. The Fan Festival, in particular, will help extend the World Cup experience to a wider audience, ensuring that even those without tickets can enjoy the festivities.In addition to the economic benefits, the event also highlights Miami's growing prominence as a cultural and entertainment hub. The city's diverse offerings, from its vibrant nightlife to its rich cultural heritage, will complement the global energy surrounding the World Cup, attracting even more travelers in the years to come.Miami's World Cup Investment and its Impact on Local TourismMiami-Dade County's 46 million USD push for the 2026 FIFA World Cup is big news for everyone, from lifelong locals to the fans flying in for the games. The FIFA Fan Festival is the centerpiece everyone should circle on their calendars. Free to enter, it's the ultimate soccer block party where you can watch every match on giant screens, enjoy food from around the world, and feel the stadium buzz without ever buying a ticket. Sure, some folks question the price tag, but the payoff in hotel bookings, restaurant lines, and airport crowds is hard to ignore. Bayern Munich make late move to rival Chelsea's transfer interest in Xavi Simons
Source: Goal.com    Published: 2025-08-16 10:55:16

Bayern Munich look set to miss out on signing Xavi Simons after the RB Leipzig star reiterated his desire to join Chelsea this summer.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Chelsea vs Crystal Palace Prediction, Odds, and Best Bet for Premier League Week 1
Source: Sports Illustrated    Published: 2025-08-16 10:00:02

I pegged this game as the most interesting to bet on in Week 1 because both Chelsea and Crystal Palace have high hopes coming into this season, but it's hard to envision both London-based teams reaching them. Chelsea finished fourth in the Premier League last year and won the UEFA Conference League trophy. They kept the momentum going in the offseason, winning the FIFA Club World Cup title with a shocking 3-0 victory over defending Champions League winner PSG in the final. They've won two friendlies since then and seem primed to compete for a top-three spot in the Prem and possibly add a trophy or two along the way. Palace were in the lower half of the table last season, but won the FA Cup in a shocking final against Manchester City and just beat defending EPL champions Liverpool in the Community Shield match. They could compete for other trophies and perhaps a top-six finish in the league. Both teams enter the season feeling quite confident after outstanding finishes to last season and some big wins in the preseason this year. Chelsea is superior and playing at home, which could make all the difference in this one. Let's get into it starting with the odds via FanDuel Sportsbook. Chelsea have Top 3 finish aspirations, but any hope of actually competing for a title will come down to taking care of business against mid-tier teams like Palace. They tied their two matches last year, 1-1 each time, and can ill afford to leave points on the pitch again this season to reach those lofty goals. A Premier League title seems out of reach, yet hope abounds at Stamford Bridge, and playing at home to start is a big boon for a team looking to celebrate its Club World Cup win. Palace retained the majority of the team that won the FA Cup last year, and that showed in their comeback win over Liverpool less than a week ago. However, it's likely too tough an ask to beat two Prem powers in a week, especially on the road in front of a raucous crowd. Enzo Maresca is in his second year as Chelsea's manager and has established the club as a defensive stalwart. Indeed, in their recent Club World Cup win, they held high-scoring PSG scoreless in the final and conceded three goals in seven matches total. Meanwhile, their offense hasn't scored fewer than two goals this preseason. I see a letdown for Palace coming off their surprise win over Liverpool. Chelsea will be ready to pounce. Create a new FanDuel Sportsbook account, and you can get $300 in bonus bets if you win your first $5 wager. Download the FanDuel app and deposit a minimum of $5 to claim your FanDuel Promo Code today. Odds refresh periodically and are subject to change. If you or someone you know has a gambling problem and wants help, call 1-800-GAMBLER. Brian Giuffra is the VP of Betting Content at Minute Media and has been with the company since 2016. He's a fan of the Knicks, Giants, wine and bourbon, usually consuming them in that order. Emotional Arne Slot admits he had wanted to bring late Diogo Jota on as a substitute in Liverpool's dramatic victory over Bournemouth
Source: Goal.com    Published: 2025-08-16 08:42:17

Arne Slot says he "would have loved" to have brought on Diogo Jota in a heartbreaking admission following Liverpool's dramatic 4-2 win over Bournemouth on Friday.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Chelsea now believe in their process but need to stay humble for title tilt
Source: The Guardian    Published: 2025-08-16 07:00:00

Board are not demanding a Premier League win but silencing talk will be impossible if Club World Cup winners make fast start Off we go again. Just over a month has passed since Chelsea stunned Paris Saint-Germain in the Club World Cup final, Cole Palmer leading the destruction of the European champions. But there is no chance of life at Stamford Bridge slowing down. It has been another breathless summer and, while the vibe is as positive as it has ever been under the ownership of Clearlake Capital and Todd Boehly, there is also the unavoidable question of whether a relentless schedule is going to catch up with the new world champions further down the line. A compressed pre-season, limited to friendlies against Bayer Leverkusen and Milan last weekend, may pose complications for Enzo Maresca in the long run. Chelsea had a lucrative time in the US, earning an estimated £85m in prize money, but the riches on offer from Fifa's expanded tournament come with potential costs. The unknown is how last season, stretching until 13 July, will affect Maresca's players. They looked ready to go during convincing wins in the pair of friendlies, which suggests there will be no lethargy when they open their Premier League campaign with a testing home game against Crystal Palace on Sunday, but one theory is problems will come when the Champions League begins, the fixtures pile up and Christmas approaches There has already been one setback, the loss of Levi Colwill to an anterior cruciate ligament injury leaving a sizeable hole at the back. Chelsea do not intend to panic and sign a defender for the sake of it, despite Maresca saying on Friday he wanted a replacement for Colwill. Chelsea's position is that they have depth and they will move only if someone suitable is available. Maresca feels his squad does not have anyone as proficient as Colwill at making his tactics work. “We know how important he has been,” he said last week. “I spoke with Levi and told him that if we achieved what we achieved last year it is also because of him.” It speaks volumes that Colwill was the one constant presence in central defence. His defending improved during the run-in, he has developed as a leader and his ability on the ball makes him crucial to the buildup. Chelsea feel they have internal solutions. Trevoh Chalobah, back in favour after being loaned to Palace at the start of last season, was outstanding against PSG. Wesley Fofana, who was first choice next to Colwill before breaking down last December, will be vital if he can stay fit. Other options include Benoît Badiashile and Tosin Adarabioyo, often seen acting as Palmer's chaperone, and the young prospects Josh Acheampong and Aarón Anselmino. There is also a potential solution in Jorrel Hato, even if the new arrival from Ajax has been signed initially to compete with Marc Cucurella at left-back. It is hardly a crisis. The squad is deep and it is not a case of quantity over quality this time. There have been a lot of sales again – the intention is for Chelsea's spending to be at net zero when the window shuts – but the business is better than last year. The attack has been upgraded with the signings of João Pedro and Liam Delap. Dário Essugo and Andrey Santos provide promising cover for Enzo Fernández and Moisés Caicedo in midfield. Jamie Gittens has replaced Jadon Sancho on the left and Estêvão Willian, a prodigious Brazilian talent who shone for Palmeiras during the Club World Cup, offered exciting glimpses against Leverkusen and Milan. Then there is the ice-cold Palmer, who took the first steps towards superstardom with his brilliant double against PSG. He is the team's undoubted star, the key difference-maker, although it is important Chelsea are not reliant on one individual. Insiders stress this is a team effort. There is consistent praise for the youth-driven strategy implemented by the recruitment team of Paul Winstanley, Laurence Stewart, Sam Jewell and Joe Shields. The quartet have faced external criticism but were handed contract extensions this week. It is hard for anyone to argue that Chelsea, who also won the Conference League last season, are not on the right track after seeing how Maresca outdid Luis Enrique's PSG. Two years after they finished 12th, a proper title challenge does not feel unrealistic. Chelsea have firepower and tactical flexibility, and they have belief after beating PSG. Inside the club, though, there is caution. Maresca is not facing demands from the board to win the title. The victory over PSG has been followed by reminders of the need for everyone to stay humble. There is a wariness about anyone involved in the project getting carried away. Chelsea are a young team and came close to missing out on Champions League qualification last season. Dips are to be expected and Robert Sánchez's recent improvement has not fully allayed doubts over whether he is a title-winning goalkeeper. Maresca, too, was under pressure after Christmas. Chelsea, though, crave stability. They want mid-season managerial changes to be a thing of the past. They are not going to overreact if fatigue hits after Champions League games or during the festive period. Sign up to Football Daily Kick off your evenings with the Guardian's take on the world of football after newsletter promotion Chelsea believe in their process. The trading can look ruthless but the model of handing out heavily incentivised deals has made it easier to move unwanted players. Noni Madueke has gone to Arsenal for an initial £48m. There were no issues shipping João Félix to Saudi Arabia. A bigger challenge is finding buyers for Raheem Sterling and Christopher Nkunku, both of whom were signed on big wages before Chelsea shifted their contract policy. Further incomings depend on more sales, with Ben Chilwell and Carney Chukwuemeka also hoping for fresh starts. Chelsea want to strengthen in the final third by signing Manchester United's Alejandro Garnacho and RB Leipzig's Xavi Simons but being fined by Uefa for breaching financial fair play rules heightens the need to raise money, which will most likely come through selling Nkunku, Nicolas Jackson and Tyrique George. It will be busy before the window shuts. It is never quiet at Chelsea. Maresca tried to play down their chances last season, saying they were not ready to challenge Liverpool and Arsenal, but silencing the title talk will be impossible if they hit the ground running this time.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Is turbo-nostalgia ruining people's enjoyment of contemporary football?
Source: The New York Times    Published: 2025-08-16 04:07:32

EPL To anyone who remembers World Cup 2010, the Jabulani football was, by common consent, a major factor in contributing to an underwhelming tournament in South Africa. Its unusual construction, featuring fewer panels than any ball before or since, meant a lack of ‘drag', so the ball didn't decelerate properly, and moved unpredictably late. It had long been a cliche for goalkeepers to complain about a new tournament ball, but in 2010 outfielders were appalled too. Advertisement “It's taken some of the skill out of the game,” complained England midfielder Joe Cole. Brazil's Robinho agreed. “The guy who designed this ball never played football,” he said. “But there's nothing we can do.” Yet if you spot the Jabulani mentioned 15 years on, it's often in positive, fond terms. “Every league in the world should be required to use the Jabulani on a random week of the season,” read one viral tweet last season. “Every game would be chaos. Goals being scored from everywhere.“ But hang on: that was the opposite of what the Jabulani offered. It didn't produce chaos; it contributed to the second-lowest goals-per-game rate of any World Cup (after the 1990 edition that was so tedious that it led to the introduction of the backpass rule to reform the sport). The winners, Spain, triumphed largely because they kept the fly-away ball on the ground, but they scored just eight goals in seven games. As for ‘goals being scored from everywhere': there were the same number of goals scored from outside the box in 2010, 26, as at World Cup 2006. And while that was simply one light-hearted tweet, others convey a similar message, suggesting the Jabulani was “a blessing for spectators”, or “the best ball ever made” or, inevitably, “the GOAT ball”, all of which is the complete opposite of what everyone thought at the time. This about-turn is presumably not because people have reconsidered what they want from a football. It's because they've spent 15 years seeing the same three goals again: Giovanni van Bronkhorst's top corner strike against Uruguay, Keisuke Honda's swerving free kick against Denmark, and one of two Diego Forlan free kicks. And when goals did go in, the unconventional trajectory of the Jabulani was oddly fascinating. But we haven't re-watched all the terrible shots, all the misplaced long-range passes, and all the things that made for a World Cup which was flatter than the bellow of the vuvuzelas. Advertisement Rose-tinted spectacles are nothing new, particularly when it comes to sport. A common pattern is that everyone's favourite World Cup is generally the first they experienced, which might explain why World Cup 2010 seems popular with people who are probably now in their mid-twenties. But football coverage — and, let's be honest, the wider world — still hasn't quite got to grips with how easily-accessible bitesize clips of the past have warped our perception of the present. We are living in an age of turbo-nostalgia. It is simpler than ever, for example, to create a playlist that demonstrates why your favourite year of music (bonus points if this was the same year as your favourite World Cup) was so great. What once involved buying and assembling various records, cassettes or CDs and manually recording the music can be performed on Spotify in a couple of minutes. And, of course, someone's already done it for you anyway, so you can just click on that playlist. And if you subsequently click on the ‘best new music' playlist, it just won't be as good. Because, obviously, you're comparing one random week to your favourite-ever year. The effect in football occurs in various forms, but chiefly when comparing individual players. Whenever up-and-coming footballers are asked for their favourite all-time player, the most common answers are Lionel Messi and Cristiano Ronaldo, but an intriguing number select Ronaldo and Zinedine Zidane, even if they were born after those players retired. The era of YouTube means you can watch them as easily as, say, Erling Haaland. And their best bits are better, in part because they have a whole career to select from. Ronaldo and Zidane have become so adored based upon, say, that goal against Compostela or that Champions League winner against Bayer Leverkusen — and various compilations — that there's actually no rational analysis about their careers. People think you've some kind of vendetta if you point out that Ronaldo only won one league title in Europe and never got close to winning the European Cup, or recall that Zidane had a disastrous 18-month period between winning World Cup 1998 and Euro 2000 when he looked completely bereft of confidence, and both Juventus and Real Madrid improved when he left. But if we speak about, say, Kylian Mbappe in those terms, it's only applying the current standard of scrutiny to the past. Advertisement So, George Weah's goal for Milan versus Verona in 1996 was brilliant, and yes, he won that year's Ballon d'Or, but he also only scored seven goals that calendar year. Yes, that scary bloke Duncan Ferguson (who the commentators insist Everton ‘could do with out there today!') scored lots of thumping headers, but his best-ever return in a season, from over a decade in the Premier League, was 11 goals, which was one more than Beto scored in 2024-25. But almost any retrospective coverage of anything in football — particularly, it must be said, from the 1990s — is so overwhelmingly positive to the point of delusion. “When you watch football in the Premier League or other top divisions, it's so robotic,” said David McGoldrick, briefly an enigmatic Premier League forward for Sheffield United, now at Barnsley in League One. “In my day, there was Ronaldinho, Paul Gascoigne and those kinds of players who were great to watch.” But those two players' careers barely overlapped. They peaked about 15 years apart. They were considered special cases even at the time. And the current era does have, for example, Lamine Yamal. The current vibe amongst football fans is not solely typical nostalgia felt solely by middle-aged people, but an intense level of anemoia — as American writer John Koenig has termed it — essentially, false nostalgia for a time you can't recall. Even teenagers insist they're ‘against modern football', and think ‘the game has gone', which could conceivably be because modern football truly is rubbish, and the game has actually gone. But they're all still hooked on it, so, to paraphrase Ron Atkinson, it must be not-bad then. All this would basically be fine, and completely unworthy of any comment, if it wasn't compromising people's enjoyment of what's actually happening in their own time. The reaction to Euro 2024 — a perfectly good competition that produced some excellent games and best major tournament winner for well over a decade — was strange. “Why is Euro 2024 so dull?,” was the headline in The Spectator. “One of the poorest tournaments we've seen in a long time,” claimed former Sky Sports presenter Richard Keys. But it was surely better than both Euro 2020, which was compromised by geography, Covid-19 and a lack of convincing sides, and Euro 2016, a tournament which never really took off. Again, people were presumably comparing watching 120 minutes of a flat game to a couple of standout, YouTube-aided memories from otherwise dull tournaments. Away from football, this has more serious ramifications. A poll by YouGov last year asked around 2,000 people, grouped by age, when they thought life was best. Those aged 70+ generally thought it was the 1960s, people in their sixties thought it was the 1970s, people in their 50s thought it was the 1980s, and so on. That was, in itself, funny but not surprising — everyone enjoyed being young. A more interesting side story was that people in their twenties were more likely than older generations to point to periods before they were born as the best time to have lived, which surely results in flawed perceptions of the current day. Comparatively, the ‘make football great again' vibe is mostly harmless. But for the record, as the new Premier League campaign gets underway, the quality of technical and tactical play is better than ever, the goals-per-game rate has reached incredibly high levels over the last couple of seasons, attendances are at record numbers, and the English top flight is now unquestionably the best around. Let's try to enjoy it. In 2040, some will speak about this as the GOAT season — even if this campaign is as bad as the Jabulani was. (Top photo: Shaun Botterill/Getty Images) Spot the pattern. Connect the terms Find the hidden link between sports terms Play today's puzzle Michael Cox concentrates on tactical analysis. He is the author of two books - The Mixer, about the tactical evolution of the Premier League, and Zonal Marking, about footballing philosophies across Europe. Follow Michael on Twitter @Zonal_Marking
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


TENNIS

Tennis LIVE: Emma Raducanu handed crushing blow as star withdraws from US Open
Source: Daily Express    Published: 2025-08-16 19:13:00

live This year's Cincinnati Open is back on track following the extreme weather that disrupted play on Tuesday. Play was curtailed early with the main court flooded as torrential rain lashed down, but thankfully, there has been no such disruption since. In the men's draw, Jannik Sinner will face qualifier Terence Atmane in his semi-final today before Carlos Alcaraz faces Alexander Zverev. The women's singles is wide open though after world No.1 Aryna Sabalenka was knocked out by Elena Rybakina, and Coco Gauff is also out after defeat to Jasmine Paolini. Elsewhere, Emma Raducanu is ramping up her preparation ahead of the US Open. Follow our live updates below... Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions, and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. It's almost time for the first match of the day, with Jannik Sinner set to face qualifier Terence Atmane. Terence Atmane is set for a clash against Jannik Sinner at the Cincinnati Open. The qualifier said: "I don't think any words can describe how I feel right now. It's pretty insane to be honest. I cannot believe it. "Being here in the semi-finals of a Masters 1000, breaking into the Top 100 and even more with the win tonight - it's also a lot of money for me, so it's going to be very helpful for my career. It means a lot to me. I'm very emotional about it." The Spanish ace has lost more times than he's won against Alexander Zverev. The pair face each other in the Cincinnati Open last four later today. Barbie has unveiled a Venus Williams doll as part of its Inspiring Women collection. The news comes after she confirmed her entry for this year's US Open. Here's how the news was announced on social media... A post shared by Barbie (@barbie) British No.1 Jack Draper has re-paired with Jessica Pegula for the revamped US Open mixed doubles tournament. Paula Badosa pulled out this week, leaving Draper without a partner. However, him and Pegula are now back together and will be seeded at Flushing Meadows. Tennis courts in Warwickshire have reopened following a near £75,000 refurbishment. Rugby Borough Council has confirmed the facilities at Caldecott Park now boast have new hard court surfaces, net posts, nets, security gates and fencing. It comes after the council secured a £50,000 grant from the Lawn Tennis Association (LTA) and its Tennis Foundation's Park Tennis Project, which is supported by government funding. Coco Gauff has brushed off criticism of her form after struggling since her French Open win. Following her defeat to Jasmine Paolini in Cincinnati, she delivered this riposte in her post-match press conference... Coco Gauff perspective\u201cSometimes tennis fans want us to win like every week. But we\u2019re playing 11 months. It\u2019s not that easy, so its completely normal for a player to have a good 3-4 weeks, then maybe a not so good 3-4 weeks just bcuz the way our season is built\u201d\ud83c\udfa5: WTA, DAZN pic.twitter.com/hHJU3lKiSr Carlos Alcaraz has admitted he lost concentration before overcoming Andrey Rublev 6-3 4-6 7-5 to make the semi-finals in Cincinnati. “I maintained positive thoughts all the time, even though I lost focus a few times during the second set,” he said. “Playing someone like Andrey, when you lose focus on two or three points, it can cost you the set or almost the match. I just stayed strong mentally and that's what I'm most proud of.” Alexander Zverev has admitted to not feeling fully fit ahead of his semi-final with Carlos Alcaraz. After beating Ben Shelton, the star admitted: "Right now I'm not feeling too great, we'll see I have a day to get fresh and to hopefully feel 100% again. "I'm not sure what happened, I came out today and probably felt the best I did in a few months, but dnd of the first set started feeling not so great and got progressively worse." American influencer Costeen Hatzi has said she was fully supportive of partner Nick Kyrgios before their split in 2024. “I went to all the tournaments. I was doing everything behind the scenes, his washing, his cooking, everything,” she told News Corp. Refusing to criticise her ex, she added: “I was happy to, because I loved him and we had a great relationship at the time. So I don't regret anything that I've done. We still had a beautiful relationship, even though things didn't turn out the way I'd hoped. I hope he's happy. I don't wish bad upon him at all.” Emma Raducanu has hit back over criticism of her constant coaching changes. Speaking ahead of the US Open, she said: “I'm a lot more clear on what I do and don't like. "The experiences that I've had with different coaches, people love to say I've had so many different coaches but if I went into the details of a lot of them, people wouldn't say the same thing. I just don't do that, because I don't want to 'out' these people. I keep it to myself.” Just a day after being backed by Lindsey Davenport, Ben Shelton became the last American player to fall at the Cincinnati Open overnight. He was well beaten 6-2 6-2 by Alexander Zverev, and looked crestfallen as he approached the net afterwards. The top two seeds in the women's draw are out after quarter-final defeats overnight. Favourite Aryna Sabalenka was stunned 1-6 4-6 by Elena Rybakina, before Gauff lost Jasmine Paolini. Here's the moment that Sabelanka was dumped out... That was a Rybakina MASTERCLASS \ud83e\udd29Elena Rybakina knocks out defending champion Sabalenka 6-1, 6-4.#CincyTennis pic.twitter.com/J03v3ncKUR Danielle Collins has announced that she will end her season after the US Open. On Instagram, the world No. 57 said she was preparing for her last tournament of the year. Collins was set to retire at the end of 2024, but changed her mind in October as she bravely opened up on her fertility journey. The American played on this year, and it's not known what her plans are for 2026. A post shared by Danielle Collins (@danimalcollins) Veronika Kudermetova is through to the semi-finals in Cincinnati, where she will face either Coco Gauff or Jasmine Paolini. The former top-10 star, who currently sits at No. 36 in the world, thrashed Varvara Gracheva 6-1 6-2 on Friday to reach the last four here for the first time in her career. Carlos Alcaraz is through to the Cincinnati Open semi-final after beating Andrey Rublev 6-3 4-6 7-5. The Spaniard served for the match in the third set but got broken. When Rublev served to stay in the match while trailing 5-6, he double-faulted on match point, gifting Alcaraz the victory. The world No. 2 had a huge reaction, roaring and pumping his fists multiple times. Alcaraz will face either Ben Shelton or Alexander Zverev on Saturday. Jannik Sinner was set to join forces with Emma Navarro at the revamped US Open mixed doubles event next week. But organisers of the WTA 500 in Monterrey have now announced that Navarro has made the last-minute decision to enter their tournament, which means she won't be around for the doubles. The Abierto GNP Seguros runs from August 16 to 23. The US Open mixed doubles matches will be played on August 19 and 20. Play has just resumed in Alcaraz and Rublev's quarter-final after a fan in the stands became unwell. The Spaniard held for 1-0 to start the third set when play was paused as chair umpire Mohamed Lahyani noticed a spectator struggling. Lahyani rushed over with water and an umbrella, and Alcaraz watched on until the fan eventually left the stands. Carlos Alcaraz's quarter-final clash with Andrey Rublev has gone to a third and final set. The Spaniard broke twice in the opening set to take it 6-3. But the No. 9 seed has just pagged him back, winning the second set 6-4. Coco Gauff recently revealed that she had been forced to delete X (formerly known as Twitter) because she became obsessed with following Love Island USA on the app. Now, Ben Shelton has jumped on the bandwagon, admitting that he deleted the app years ago. "I remember two years ago, I ended up deleting Twitter from my phone, and that was the best decision I ever made. Now, two years have passed, and I've never read anything on that social network again," the recent Canadian Open champion told Tennis Channel. "I prefer to watch the highlights of certain matches. At the moment, I watch a lot of the tennis matches I used to watch, whether it's from the tournament I'm playing in or even from a Challenger tournament that's happening that week. I have a team that helps me keep my feet on the ground." Andrey Rublev is currently trailing Carlos Alcaraz by a break in the opening set of their quarter-final. And the No. 9 seed isn't happy with some of the automated technology - even if he doesn't realise some of it is automated. Rublev confronted chair umpire Mohamed Lahyani and claimed the shot clock was being started too soon, only to be told that it automatically started three seconds after the last point was called. Then, he was shown a replay of an electronic line call he didn't agree with, and thought the wrong ball may have been shown. The chair umpire had to ask Aryna Sabalenka to rip the label off her water bottle during her quarter-final defeat to Elena Rybakina. The world No. 1 was drinking from a plastic San Pellegrino bottle when the official said: "Aryna can I just ask you to take [the label] off that bottle? Perfect, thank you, we're good, that's fine." It comes just a couple of days after Carlos Alcaraz became frustrated when an umpire told him off for drinking from reusable branded Evian bottles. "It's not my fault," the Spaniard repeatedly stated. Last year's Cincinnati Open champion, Aryna Sabalenka, has been ousted in the quarter-final. Elena Rybakina has taken out the top seed 6-1 6-4, ending Sabalenka's title defence. She saved all five break points she faced, and will face Iga Swiatek in the semi-finals. British doubles stars Lloyd Glasspool and Julian Cash have extended their incredible winning streak in Cincinnati. They've now won 22 matches and counting after beating No. 6 seed Andrea Vavassori and Simone Bolelli in the quarter-finals. Dubbed 'Cashpool', they have not lost a match since the Libema Open final in June. The Brits swept titles at Queen's, Eastbourne, Wimbledon and Toronto, and they're looking for their fifth successive trophy. Elena Rybakina is off to a flying start in her Cincinnati Open quarter-final against world No. 1 and defending champion Aryna Sabalenka. Rybakina suffered a brutal defeat to Sabalenka in Berlin a few weeks ago, blowing four match points to go out in the quarter-finals. But she's keen to get revenge - she's taken the first set 6-1 in Cincinnati in under half an hour. Iga Swiatek had the fans on Cincinnati Open's centre court in stitches as she discussed the searing heat. Asked how she was coping in the hot weather, the world No. 3 had a simple answer - she'd been drinking. But she made it very clear that she was keeping things pure and healthy. “There's no secret, I just drink,” she said, before eyeing the camera and adding: “But water!” Iga Swiatek is through to her third straight semi-final at the Cincinnati Open after beating Anna Kalinskaya 6-3 6-4. The world No. 3 has never been beyond the semis here. If she wants to reach the final, she'll have to beat either Aryna Sabalenka or Elena Rybakina. Their match is up next on the centre court. Terence Atmane has enjoyed a breakthrough week in Cincinnati, coming through qualifying and making it all the way to tomorrow's semi-final, where he takes on Jannik Sinner. The French qualifier has already beaten 15th seed Flavio Cobolli, teenage sensation Joao Fonseca, and top-10 stars Taylor Fritz and Holger Rune on his way to the last four. Ranked down at No. 136 in the world, Atmane is set to bank at least £245k in prize money and will make his top 100 debut when the tournament is over. But he still has no clothing or shoe sponsor after being dropped by Asics last year. “Apart from Tecnifibre for the rackets, I don't have any sponsors since I got dropped by Asics. I buy my clothes and shoes like everyone else. I don't have an agent; I do my thing on my own in my corner,” Atmane told L'Equipe. Anna Kalinskaya sparked concerns when she called the physio and received a medical time-out minutes into her Cincinnati Open quarter-final clash with Iga Swiatek. The No. 28 seed already had heavy strapping on her shoulder, and during the first changeover in the match, with Swiatek leading 2-1, the trainer bandaged Kalinskaya's calf. She has decided to play on and got broken. Swiatek currently leads 4-1. Terence Atmane is on the run of his life in Cincinnati. The world No. 136 qualifier is into the semi-finals after beating two top-10 players, including Holger Rune. After suffering a 6-2 6-3 defeat in the quarters, Rune took to social media to send some words of support to Atmane. "I have known you Terence since juniors, tennis is a tough journey and I am happy for your run here at @CincyTennis and what it will mean in the future for you . Good luck onwards," he tweeted. Play is getting underway at the Cincinnati Open, with No. 3 seed and recent Wimbledon champion Iga Swiatek facing Anna Kalinskaya for a spot in the semi-finals. Kalinskaya hit out at the WTA when their quarter-final was scheduled first on Friday at 11am local time, after her last match started on Wednesdan night and finished in the early hours on Thursday, and she didn't get to bed until 4am. “How can the WTA and tournament expect athletes to perform their best when the scheduling is unfair?” she wrote in an Instagram story. “After my match against Alexandrova, I got home from the site at 2:40 am and didn't go to bed until 4 am. I slept a bit and came to the site to practice.” “Then I get scheduled at 11 am for tomorrow's match—how does the tournament and WTA expect me to recover and continuously adjust my sleep pattern, which is one of the most important aspects of recovery? Seems a bit one sided.” Emma Raducanu made a statement at Wimbledon last month, where she put up an impressive fight during a tight loss to Aryna Sabalenka in the third round. But her private life was also under the spotlight at SW19, as Raducanu was asked whether there was any truth to rumours that she was dating Carlos Alcaraz, whom she'll team up with in the US Open mixed doubles event next week. After she said they were just friends, fellow British player Cameron Norrie - who is in a long-term relationship - was asked whether he was seeing Raducanu. And the 22-year-old has finally responded to the intrusive speculation. “Yeah, and Cam's questions, too. That was terrible. Terrible,” she told the Guardian. The International Tennis Integrity Agency have confirmed that Japanese star Kaili Demi Teso has been suspended for 10 months following a doping violation.The 19-year-old Teso tested positive for the prohibited substance methylephedrine, atributed to a bottle of cough medicine. Teso's mother, also his manager, acquired the medicine on the player's behalf and the ITIA accepted that the breach was not intentional. In a statement, they said: "An independent tribunal issued a ruling of no significant fault or negligence and a 10-month suspension, noting that the player's mother had consulted a professional from a reputable pharmacy before purchasing, and that Teso, 18 at the time of the positive test, was inexperienced." Wimbledon commentator Andrew Castle has claimed the 'Royal Box' jibe from Andre Agassi live on air this summer was blown out of proportion. "We had a laugh, and they took it out of context," he told Betway. "Afterwards, Andre sent me a text, saying what an unbelievable time he'd had, how he enjoyed it, and we were going to have him for the final but then he went into the Royal Box instead. "But then you read that he was saying, oh, ‘just concentrate on the tennis'." Andre Agassi pretty much annoyed by Andrew Castle and his obsession with celebrities in the Royal Box. Andre is right, it's tennis that they came to concentrate on. Lindsey Davenport has backed Ben Shelton to win the US Open. Davenport, who won three Slam crowns in an illustrious career, said on the Tennis Channel: "Ben Shelton has that type of game where he can take the racket out of his opponent's hand. "He's got big weapons. He's such an explosive athlete. He lights up the stadium as well. If you get on a roll in New York, if he can play that high level tennis and have the crowd behind him, we could have an American male Grand Slam champion here pretty soon." Andrey Rublev had received a significant boost ahead of the US Open this month. The 27-year-old will face Carlos Alcaraz in the quarter-finals of the Cincinnati Open, having learnt that his coach, Marat Safin, has received his US visa. Safin won't be able to join him in Ohio, but will be in New York to guide him for Flushing Meadows this month. Jannik Sinner has defended his decision to rehire fitness coach Umberto Ferrer after his latest win in Cincinatti. Having sacked Ferrer following his doping controversy, Sinner said:"It was a different situation. Now everything is different. I felt like, at this point, I needed someone who knew my body better. "We worked together for about two years before this break. His work has brought me a lot of benefits. We worked on every area of my body and my endurance has improved. I think he did a great job." Roger Federer has learnt who he will share a court with for his celebrity doubles match in Shanghai on October 10. It's been confirmed that he'll partner with one of two actors, Hong Kong film star Donnie Yen or Chinese TV personality Wu Lei, to play against ex-professional female Zheng Jie. The US Open mixed doubles partnership between Emma Raducanu and Carlos Alcaraz appears in doubt due to the Cincinnati Open schedule. Alcaraz is into the last eight, and if he makes Monday's final, he will play just 20 hours before the revamped tournament gets underway. Having taken a break after Wimbledon, citing fatigue, former British player Barry Fulcher has speculated Alcaraz could now follow Coco Gauff in skipping the team event. Emma Raducanu has revealed she has been training in extreme heat ahead of the US Open this month. After her exit in Cincinnati, Raducanu took to her Instagram story to post a picture of her sweating profusely after a training session. She's already stated she feels she is heading to Flushing Meadows in the best shape since her win there four years ago. French qualifier Terence Atmane continued his sensational run at the ATP Cincinnati Masters last night by stunning seventh-seeded Holger Rune 6-2, 6-3. The world No.136 now in his Masters 1000 semi-final where he'll face defending champion Jannik Sinner. "I don't think any words can describe how I feel right now," said the 23-year-old. "I was just trying to be myself on the court." Here's the moment he sealed his win... Atmane = THE MAN \ud83d\udd25The moment World No.136 Terence Atmane defeated Rune to become the first qualifier to reach the #CincyTennis semi-finals since 2015! pic.twitter.com/svq87YhYQJ Alexander Zverev has admitted he got professional help following his first round exit at Wimbledon this summer. "I took a longer period of time off after Wimbledon, which I haven't done in a very long time," he said. "Which was very needed. I didn't train, I didn't do any physical work, I didn't play tennis for a longer time as well which was the best thing for me to do. I enjoyed my time, mentally freed up, got also some professional help as well there. I'm happy to be back on court." Anna Kalinskaya has accused the WTA of being 'biased' against her due to the scheduling of her upcoming match against Iga Swiatek. On her Instagram story, she wrote: "How does the WTA and the tournament expect their players to play well with these unfair schedules? "After my match against Alexandrova, I went home at 2:40am and didn't go to bed until 4:00am. "I slept a little and came back to train today. Then they scheduled my match tomorrow [against Swiatek] at 11:00am. "How does the WTA and the tournament expect me to recover and continue adjusting my sleep patterns, when that's one of the most important aspects of recovery? It seems a bit biased." Jannik Sinner is through to the semi-finals in Cincinnati after securing a dominant win over Felix Auger-Aliassime. The young Italian turned the screw to earn a 6-0 6-2 victory in one hour and 11 minutes. He will be hoping to go all the way and lift the trophy to give himself some winning momentum ahead of the US Open. Jasmine Paolini will go up against Coco Gauff in the quarter-finals of the Cincinnati Open. She has booked her place in the last eight with a thumping win over former Wimbledon champion Barbora Krejcikova. Paolini was in full control throughout and sailed to a comprehensive 6-1 6-2 victory. Emma Raducanu will not be seeded for the US Open, it has been confirmed. Veronika Kudermetova's recent victory over Clara Tauson at the Cincinnati Open pushed the young Brit out of the final spot. It means Raducanu could face a top player in the very first round at Flushing Meadows. Coco Gauff is safely through to the quarter-finals of the Cincinnati Open after beating Lucia Bronzetti in straight sets. The young American turned on the style to secure a one-sided 6-2 6-4 victory. She will face either seventh seed Jasmine Paolini or former Wimbledon winner Barbora Krejcikova in the next round. Patrick Mouratoglou is convinced that Victoria Mboko will win Grand Slam titles over the course of her career. Reflecting on her incredible Canadian Open triumph, he said: "She plays to win no matter who is on the other side of the court. "She started the year ranked 300. Difficult to think she's not going to win Grand Slams. "Great physicality, the way she moves on the court and she's very offensive, both sides forehand and backhand." Male tennis players will pocket a record £13.5m in profit-sharing bonuses from the 2024 season, the ATP have confirmed. The figure marks an increase of 177 per cent on the previous season's payout. It will be distributed to players based on their performance at the nine ATP 1000 tournaments. ATP chairman Andrea Gaudenzi said: "This is exactly what profit sharing was designed to do, ensure that players and tournaments share equally in the sport's financial upside. "It is a huge milestone. For us, it's proof that strengthening the premium product and aligning interests creates value. "We're proud to be strengthening our partnership and building a stronger, more sustainable ATP Tour." Matteo Berrettini has pulled out of the US Open due to an injury. He has not played since Wimbledon, where he was dumped out by Kamil Majchrzak in five sets. Berrettini skipped Toronto and Cincinnati with the aim of recovering in time for the final Grand Slam of the year. However, he remains unable to compete and has withdrawn from the event. Aryna Sabalenka has admitted to regularly cheating on her diet. In an interview with the Tennis Channel during the Cincinnati Open, she said: “It's hamburgers, it can be pizza, it can be gummies. It can be a lot of different things in one day because you know, like if it's a cheat meal, you got to go full. “But hamburgers, that's my weakness, cheesy and soft and a really good meat and hot and the bun is still melting with the cheese.” The International Tennis Integrity Agency has confirmed Australian tennis player Thomas Fancutt has accepted a 10 month suspension for a doping violation.Fancutt, 30, admitted to using a using a 'prohibited method' in relation to an IV drip. In a released statement, the authority said: "Following a full investigation by the ITIA, which included evidence gathering and interviews with the player, Fancutt admitted to the breach, and the ITIA accepted that the breach was not intentional." Top seeds Jannik Sinner and Aryna Sabalenka are odds-on to win the US Open. According to AceOdds, in the men's draw, Sinner is the favourite at evens ahead of Carlos Alcaraz at 2/1. In the women's draw, Aryna Sabalenka is the 5/2 favourite with Iga Swiatek closely behind at 7/2. AceOdds: 2025 US Open men's winner: Jannik Sinner Evens; Carlos Alcaraz 2/1; Novak Djokovic 16/1; Taylor Fritz, Alexander Zverev 25/1; Jack Draper 28/1; Ben Shelton 33/1; Daniil Medvedev 50/1. Women's winner: Aryna Sabalenka 5/2; Iga Swiatek 7/2; Coco Gauff 7/1; Mirra Andreeva 12/1; Elena Rybakina 14/1 Naomi Osaka 20/1; Madison Keys 22/1; Amanda Anisimova 25/1; Jessica Pegula, Emma Raducanu, Victoria Mboko 33/1; Jasmine Paolini, Clara Tauson 50/1. Jannik Sinner has learnt he won't be eligible to receive money from the ATP Masters Bonus Pool this season. The prize pot is reserved for the top performers in the six Masters 1000 events who performed in at least theee of the tournaments. While serving his doping ban, the Italian missed the Indian Wells Masters, Miami Open, and Madrid. Last month he opted to withdraw from the Toronto Masters, citing fatigue and regardless of his final position, won't be eligible for any additional money. Emma Raducanu has sent a warning to rivals ahead of the US Open this month. After struggling since her remarkable 2021 win, she's said: "I went home and came back and it was a really difficult time in New York. "Since I won the tournament, it's not been easy for me there. But this year I feel different, I'm a lot calmer behind the court. On the court, I take more confidence in the big moments." Aryna Sabalenka has withdrawn from the mixed doubles of the US Open. The world No.1 has opted not to look for a replacement after her original partner, Grigor Dimitrov, pulled out. It follows him injuring his pectoral muscle at Wimbledon when leading against Jannik Sinner. There have been contrasting reactions to Venus Williams being handed a wildcard for the US Open at 45. The world No.577 is set to become the oldest singles player in 44 years at the tournament. On social media, many fans have argued it is a 'waste' of an entry. But other believe the icon, who will also play in the revamped mixed doubles alongside fellow American Reilly Opelka, will help sell tickets in the early rounds. Anna Kalinskaya complained about 'drunk' fans during her fourth-round match against Ekaterina Alexandrova at the Cincinnati Open. Here's the moment the star approached the umpire to complain... Anna Kalinskaya on some disruptive people in the crowd during her match against Alexandrova in CincinnatiAnna: \u201cI think maybe they\u2019re drunk or something\u2026\u201dUmpire: \u201cThey probably are\u201d \ud83d\ude2d\ud83d\ude2d\ud83d\ude2d pic.twitter.com/tFut5VIfWw The former World No.6 was leading Rinderknech 7-6(4) 4-2 in their third round clash, when the Frenchman retired as he was unable to continue due to the heat. Rinderknech collapsed on the court in the second set, and subsequently threw in the towel soon after. It feels like we're in an oven, even for the fans," said Auger-Aliassime. "We're always on the move and focused on trying to win, but the crowd is sitting for a long time, and so are our coaches. A friendly reminder to everyone: drink plenty of water, bring hats, and cool off as much as possible." Carlos Alcaraz is at risk of being fined after ignoring the umpire's instructions to cover the logo on his water bottle. During his win over Luca Nardi, the Spaniard reacted angrily after official Greg Allensworth gave the order, arguing it went against tournament sponsor deals. Alcaraz refused to comply and is now likely to be sanctioned. Welcome back as we bring you all the latest tennis news from around the world. As well as Cincinnati Open updates, there are plenty of other developing stories ahead of the US Open. So make yourself a coffee and enjoy our updates. Alexander Zverev makes mental health revelation in Cincinnati after concerning statements
Source: Tennis365    Published: 2025-08-16 18:10:04

Alexander Zverev has revealed he received “professional help” having opened up about his mental state following his defeat at Wimbledon last month. After suffering a tough five-set loss to Arthur Rinderknech in the opening round at Wimbledon, Zverev revealed he had been struggling mentally since his defeat in the Australian Open final in January. “I feel very alone out there at times. I struggle mentally. I've been saying that since after the Australian Open,” the German explained in his press conference. “Yeah, just don't know. I'm trying to find ways, trying to find ways to kind of get out of this hole. I keep kind of finding myself back in it in a way. Yeah, I don't know. I feel, generally speaking, quite alone in life at the moment, which is a feeling that is not very nice.” The world No 3 added: “It's not a feeling on a tennis court, it's just a life feeling in general. As I said, I never felt this way before. I don't know. It's difficult to find joy outside the tennis court for me at the moment. “It's not an excuse or anything. I think Arthur deserved to win today. It's nothing that… It's something I've felt for the past few months. Again, I just feel generally very, very alone and very lonely. I don't know. Just never felt that way before. I don't have the answers right now.” Asked if he would consider seeking help from a therapist, Zverev said: “Maybe for the first time in my life I'll probably need it. I've been through a lot of difficulties.” Alexander Zverev's brother gives harsh reaction to his alarming Wimbledon comments Alexander Zverev reveals he is ‘not a huge fan' of one key Cincinnati Open change During the Cincinnati Masters, Zverev spoke about the benefits he is experiencing as a result of spending time away from tennis after Wimbledon. “I took a longer period of time off after Wimbledon, which I haven't done in a very long time, which was very needed,” said the 28-year-old. “I didn't train, I didn't do any physical work, I didn't play tennis for a longer time as well, which was the best thing for me to do. “And I enjoyed my time, mentally freed up, got also some professional help as well there. I'm happy to be back on court.” Zverev received advice from both Rafael Nadal — and the tennis great's uncle and former coach Toni Nadal — when training at his academy in Mallorca after Wimbledon. The German returned to action in Toronto and reached the semi-finals — and he has also progressed to the last four in Cincinnati, where he will face Carlos Alcaraz. READ NEXT: Alexander Zverev raises concerns with Cincinnati Open health confession Alexander Zverev overcame a health scare in his Cincinnati quarter-final. Alexander Zverev has made his feelings clear to the Cincinnati organisers. Ben Shelton went home with a prize cheque of more than $1m for his title-winning run in Canada. “I didn't feel my best on the court, didn't play my best tennis." © Planet Sport Limited 2025 • All Rights Reserved

ATP Cincinnati picks: Jannik Sinner vs. Terence Atmane odds, predictions, best bets
Source: New York Post    Published: 2025-08-16 14:00:00

Unless you're a tennis die-hard, you probably didn't know much about Terence Atmane before this week. The 23-year-old Frenchman is ranked as the World No. 136 and has played just 14 matches on the ATP Tour in the last calendar year. Atmane has had plenty of success on the Challenger Tour, but it hadn't translated to the big leagues — until now. To say it's a surprise that Atmane is in the semifinals at the Cincinnati Masters, one of the most prestigious tournaments outside of the Grand Slams, is a wild understatement. We've seen qualifiers make runs at big-ticket events in the past, but few have had to navigate the path that Atmane has to get to the final four. The 23-year-old defeated World No. 22 Flavio Cobolli in the Round of 64, upset rising star Joao Fonseca in his next match and then took care of Taylor Fritz and Holger Rune, two top-10 players, to set up a date with Jannik Sinner on Saturday. Sinner, as usual, has been imperious in Cincinnati. He's yet to drop a set (8-0), and he's only lost 22 games in his first four matches. That's an average of 2.75 games lost per set. Atmane is a 10/1 underdog against Sinner, but he's just pulled two massive upsets to get to this point, so he'll be brimming with confidence and playing with house money. It also wouldn't be a shock if it takes Sinner a handful of games to get used to Atmane's peculiar serve and his all-out attacking style. The Play: Terence Atmane to win the first set (+520, FanDuel) Michael Leboff is a long-suffering Islanders fan, but a long-profiting sports bettor with 10 years of experience in the gambling industry. He loves using game theory to help punters win bracket pools, find long shots, and learn how to beat the market in mainstream and niche sports.

American tennis star dumps World No. 1 in stunning U.S. Open move
Source: NJ.com    Published: 2025-08-16 10:32:00

When it was first announced that American tennis star Emma Navarro would play with world No. 1 Jannik Sinner at the reimagined Mixed Doubles event at the U.S. Open, Navarro joked that she “would try to get a better partner next year.” “He was begging me to play, he was saying, ‘I heard about your volleys and your doubles skills. Please. please play with me,” Navarro cracked last month on Tennis Channel. “I said, ‘Yeah, sure, I guess. I guess I'll play with you. You're not the best player, but I'll make an exception and try to get a better partner next year.'” Emma Navarro spills tea behind doubles partnership with Jannik Sinner 🍵 pic.twitter.com/BIeKoO0Icc Well, it turns out that Navarro won't play with Sinner at all in the $1 million event that runs Tuesday and Wednesday at the USTA Billie Jean King National Tennis Center. The No. 11-ranked player in the world and the daughter of billionaire Ben Navarro, Emma Navarro pulled out of the Mixed Doubles in order to play a WTA 500 event in Monterrey, Mexico in the week leading up to the start of the singles tournament at the U.S. Open (Aug. 24). Navarro is coming off losing early on hardcourts in Montreal and Cincinnati, and playing in Mexico will give her more practice matches heading into the U.S. Open, where she reached the semifinals a year ago. ¡GRAN SORPRESA! EMMA NAVARO #11 del mundo se suma al cuadro principal del #AbiertoGNPSeguros 2025 🤩🎾¡No te la puedes perder! pic.twitter.com/iIhNGmhZU2 According to the USTA, Sinner has until 2 p.m. on Sunday to find a new partner for the U.S. Open. The Italian is set to play in the semifinals of the Cincinnati Open on Saturday, and could face Carlos Alcaraz in Monday's championship match. Navarro, who made headlines at Wimbledon when a group of Knicks-clad fans attended her matches to support her, isn't the only big-name female star skipping the new Mixed Doubles event. World No. 2 Coco Gauff said she didn't “want to waste mental energy” on the event, while No. 1 Aryna Sabalenka and her partner Grigor Dimitrov are out after Dimitrov sustained a pectoral injury at Wimbledon. The event is still loaded with star tandems, though, including Madison Keys and Frances Tiafoe, Emma Raducanu and Alcaraz, Novak Djokovic and Olga Danilovic, Taylor Townsend and Ben Shelton and Venus Williams and Jack Draper. US Open Mixed Doubles Championship update: pic.twitter.com/Uo26UZ0oKp As for Navarro, good luck finding a “better partner” than the world No. 1 in 2026.
